thread.title: Cruise giant Carnival to enter China market, too
thread.title_full: Cruise giant Carnival to enter China market, too

title: Cruise giant Carnival to enter China market, too
text:
Carnival Cruise Line's newest ship, the Carnival Breeze. (Photo: Peter Knego)
120 CONNECT 25 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Just how hot is cruising in China? So hot that even Caribbean-focused Carnival is sending a ship there.
Industry giant Carnival Corp. on Tuesday announced the mass-market "fun ship" brand would deploy a new vessel to the country in 2017 that will be specifically aimed at the local market.
Carnival Corp.-owned Aida Cruises, a German brand, also will devote a newly-built ship to the China market in 2017, the company revealed.
The two brands are joining sister line Princess Cruises, which already has announced plans to devote its next new ship to the China market in 2017.
USA TODAY
Sign of the times? Next Princess Cruises ship to be called 盛世公主号
Carnival Corp. ( CCL ) is the parent company of Carnival, Aida, Princess and seven other cruise brands that together account for nearly half of the worldwide cruise business.
Tuesday's announcement came just a day after Miami-based Norwegian Cruise Line said it would deploy a newly-built ship to China in 2017. Royal Caribbean also is in the midst of sending two of its newest, hottest vessels to China .
The moves are a blow to North American cruisers who are accustomed to getting the latest-and-greatest ships from North America-based lines in their home markets. But the cruise industry increasingly is looking to Asia for growth, and a growing number of lines are concluding the secret to success in the region is in the deployment of new vessels.
"This is an exciting time in China for the cruise industry," Carnival Corp. CEO Arnold Donald said in a statement accompanying Tuesday's announcement. "As the world’s largest cruise company and the first global cruise operator in China, we are more committed than ever to helping China become one of the world’s most popular regions for cruise vacations.”
Carnival Corp. has been a pioneer in cruises aimed at the China market since its Costa Cruises brand first deployed a ship to the region in 2006. Three Costa ships currently are based in China with another heading to the region in 2016. The company's Princess brand first deployed a ship to China in 2014 and will have two vessels there in 2016. The new ship Princess is sending to China in 2017 will be the line's first specifically built for the Chinese market.
Carnival Corp. said it expected more than 500,000 passengers in China this year, up 43% from 2014.
The deployment of a Carnival brand vessel to China is an unusual departure for a line that is about as North American-focused as they come. Aimed at travelers looking for an affordable, easy-to-reach cruise, Carnival rarely ventures far beyond North America with its deployments, with the majority of its sailings departing from U.S. ports to the Bahamas, Caribbean, Mexico and Alaska. An exception is the recent move of a Carnival ship to Australia to cater to the Australian market.
For a deck-by-deck look at a Carnival vessel, scroll through the carousel below.
The 2004-built Carnival Miracle is the fourth in Carnival Cruise Line’s four-member Spirit Class platform, which also includes the 2001-built Carnival Spirit and Carnival Pride and the 2002-built Carnival Legend. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Carnival Miracle was built by the Kvaerner Masa Shipyard (hull number 503) at Helsinki, Finland. Originally founded as Wartsila, and recently called Aker Finnyards, it is now operating as STX Finland. Peter Knego Fullscreen Sailing year-round on cruises to Mexico and Hawaii, Carnival Miracle is based in Long Beach, California, home to the historic former Cunard Line ocean liner Queen Mary. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Spirit Class ships are immediately distinguished by the glass-framed bases of their trademark winged Carnival funnels. Peter Knego Fullscreen The 88,500-gt, 2,124-guest Carnival MIracle measures 963-by-106-feet and is powered by six diesel engines that drive two Azipods at a service speed of 22 knots. Peter Knego Fullscreen After a major refit in 2015 at the BAE Systems Drydock in San Francisco, the Carnival Miracle now boasts many of Carnival’s newly implemented 2.0 venues like the Alchemy Bar, Redfrog Pub and Skybox sports bar. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Carnival Miracle has twelve passenger decks, beginning at the top with an observation platform at the base of the ship’s funnel on Sky Deck (12). Peter Knego Fullscreen Deck 12 overlooks the midships Sports Deck (11) sunning area. Peter Knego Fullscreen The forward portion of Deck 11 is sheltered from high winds by glass panels . Peter Knego Fullscreen Forward Deck 11 features a jogging track (15.2 laps equals a mile), a basketball court and a nine hole putting course. Peter Knego Fullscreen From forward Deck 11, there is an excellent view of the Sirens and Ulysses pool areas. Peter Knego Fullscreen On midships Deck 11, there is a wide, open deck space. Peter Knego Fullscreen The aft portion of Deck 11 has a children’s wading pool and outdoor play area. Peter Knego Fullscreen At the aft end of Deck 11, there is the 72-foot, double-loop Twister water slide. Peter Knego Fullscreen Sun Deck (10) begins with a glassed in observation platform that continues aft with sunning platforms that overlook the midships pools. Peter Knego Fullscreen The aft portion of Deck 10 is lined in teak wood. Peter Knego Fullscreen Lido Deck (9) begins with an open observation platform overlooking the bow. Peter Knego Fullscreen There is an impressive aft-facing view from the open wings atop the bridge on Deck 9. Peter Knego Fullscreen The open-air Sirens Pool area features a large Jacuzzi, fresh water showers and a bronze sculpture depicting the mermaid-like Sirens from Greek mythology. Peter Knego Fullscreen Al fresco seating from the buffet dining venue Horatio’s occupies the sheltered portions of Deck 9 on either side of the Sirens and Ulysses Pool areas. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Odyssey Bar is situated between the Sirens and Ulysses Pool areas on Deck 9. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Ulysses Pool area is aft of the Sirens Pool on Deck 9 and in inclement weather can be covered with a retractable metal and glass roof. Peter Knego Fullscreen The adults-only (21 and over) Serenity area is at the aft end of Deck 9 and features a sheltered bar and lounging area. Peter Knego Fullscreen Serenity has its own pool and Jacuzzi as well as cushioned deck chairs, hammocks for two and cabanas. Peter Knego Fullscreen On Atlantic Deck (3) a wonderful teak-lined promenade stretches aft on either side to encircle the stern. When combined with the Gatsby’s Garden interior promenade, it encircles the entire deck. Peter Knego Fullscreen Located underneath the glass dome at the base of the funnel, Nick and Nora’s is the dramatically situated, 156-seat reservations-required, extra tariff ($35 per person) steakhouse aboard the Carnival Miracle. Peter Knego Fullscreen Black and white images of New York form the backdrop in Nick and Nora’s, which is perched atop the ten deck tall Metropolis Atrium. Peter Knego Fullscreen Table settings in Nick and Nora’s include Frette linens, Versace chargers, Riedel stemware and silver plate cutlery. Peter Knego Fullscreen In addition to a wide selection of steaks, lamb, lobster, a daily fish and chicken entrées, popular Nick and Nora’s courses include a caesar salad that is prepared tableside. Peter Knego Fullscreen The desserts in Nick and Nora’s run the spectrum from tiramisu and creme brulée to homemade ice creams and this delectable caramelized apple. Peter Knego Fullscreen There is a truly vertiginous view from the glass staircase that is cantilevered over the Metropolis Atrium linking the lower level of Nick and Nora’s to Horatio’s buffet dining venue. Peter Knego Fullscreen An excellent gym is located on forward Decks 10 and 9, with cardio equipment on its lowest level and terraces of exercise equipment that surround and overlook a Jacuzzi. Peter Knego Fullscreen Aft on the port side of the gym on Deck 10, there is an aerobics room that is also used for spinning classes. Peter Knego Fullscreen Carnival Miracle’s O2 Teen Center (ages 15 to 17) is on the starboard side of Deck 10. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Spa Carnival can be accessed from the forward Deck 9 stairtower lobby on the port side. Peter Knego Fullscreen There is a relaxation room at the forward end of the Spa Carnival on Deck 9. Peter Knego Fullscreen Numerous treatment rooms in the Spa Carnival offer up everything from massages and skin therapies to teeth whitening. Peter Knego Fullscreen There are separate men’s (shown) and women’s changing areas in the Spa Carnival. Peter Knego Fullscreen Each changing area in the Spa Carnival has its own Steam Room. Peter Knego Fullscreen In addition to a Steam Room, each changing area in the Spa Carnival has a Sauna. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Venus Salon is on the starboard side of Deck 9, directly across from the Spa Carnival. Peter Knego Fullscreen Horatio’s Restaurant is the Carnival Miracle’s 458-seat casual buffet dining venue on Deck 9. With a decorative nod to Horatio Hornblower, it features models of British Man-O-Wars, busts of Hornblower and the Union Jack flag. Peter Knego Fullscreen Horatio’s has food stations that include Taste of Nations (changes daily from French to Italian, American, etc.), a salad bar, Asian, a New York-style deli, a grill and a Pizzeria that makes genuine Neapolitan-style pizza. Peter Knego Fullscreen On forward Upper Deck (5), there is the Camp Carnival, which has activities for kids aged 2 - 5, 6 - 8, and 9 - 11. Peter Knego Fullscreen On forward Main Deck (4), there is the Wizard’s video arcade. Peter Knego Fullscreen Circle C, which offers facilities and activities for 11 - 15-year-olds, is next to the Wizard’s video arcade. Peter Knego Fullscreen The triple deck Phantom Show Lounge is located on forward Decks 4, 3 and 2. The Carnival Miracle’s largest entertainment venue, it seats 1,167 guests. Peter Knego Fullscreen In addition to Carnival 2.0‘s Hasbro- and Dr. Seuss-sponsored game shows and programming, the Phantom Show Room is the setting for Carnival’s lavish production shows. Peter Knego Fullscreen Gatsby’s Garden is an interior promenade that encircles the Atlantic Deck (3) level of the Phantom Show Room with seating for 52. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Ravens Library and Internet Cafe on port Deck 3 seats 23. Peter Knego Fullscreen Adjacent to the Library, Chapel and Sam’s Piano Bar, the glitzy Fountain Stairs on Deck 3 lead down to another plaza on Deck 2. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Carnival Miracle has a dedicated wedding chapel with seating for up to 30 guests on Deck 3. Peter Knego Fullscreen Inspired by the movie “Casablanca”, the 106-seat Sam’s Piano Bar on Deck 3 has colonial Moroccan decor created by longstanding former Carnival architect Joseph Farcus. Peter Knego Fullscreen Kane’s Way is an enclosed promenade area surrounding the upper level of the Fountain Stairs that seats 53 guests. Peter Knego Fullscreen Added in 2015, Cherry On Top is a candy and flower shop that is located at the forward end of the Deck 3 Yellow Brick Road shopping gallery. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Yellow Brick Road winds its way through several shops on Deck 3 that sell everything from jewelry to souvenirs and sundries. Peter Knego Fullscreen On Deck 3, a balcony runs along either side of the massive Metropolis Atrium. Peter Knego Fullscreen Pixels photo galleries are located on the port and starboard Deck 3 balconies of the Metropolis Atrium. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Gotham Lounge is aft of the Metropolis Atrium on starboard Deck 3, accommodating up to 66 guests. Peter Knego Fullscreen Adjacent to the Gotham Lounge on aft Deck 3, the City Room is a 100-seat conference room that is often used for the ship’s art auctions. Peter Knego Fullscreen Located at the aft end of Decks 3 and 2, the 1,250-seat Bacchus Dining Room is the Carnival Miracle’s main dining venue. The upper level is reserved for “Your Time” dining, where guests can dine when and where they like between 5:45 and 9:30 p.m. Peter Knego Fullscreen Table settings in the Bacchus Dining room include colorful Euro by Vortex brand chargers. Peter Knego Fullscreen Food and service in the Bacchus Dining Room is consistently of a high standard and there is a variety of international cuisine, including a spicy Indian vegetarian meal that changes nightly. Peter Knego Fullscreen Located on forward/port Promenade Deck (2), Carnival’s signature Redfrog Pub was added to the Carnival Miracle in April of 2015. The Caribbean-inspired bar accommodates 135 guests and serves rums and beers. Peter Knego Fullscreen Directly across from the Redfrog Pub on the starboard side of Deck 2, the Joker Card Room seats 20. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Fountainhead Cafe on Deck 2 is the go-to place for a la carte specialty coffees, shakes and cakes. Peter Knego Fullscreen Next to the Fountainhead Cafe on Deck 2, the Fountain Stairs descend from a suite of Deck 3 public areas. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Fun Hub is adjacent to the Fountainhead Cafe on Deck 2 and is a favorite spot for quizzes, games and even a live pianist at varying times of the day. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Sky Box is a brand new, 67-seat sports bar on Deck 2 that was added in April of 2015. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Carnival Miracle’s vast Mr. Lucky’s Casino is located on midships Deck 2, accommodating up to 278 guests. The casino has its own bar and a stage for live music. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Shore Excursions Desk is in the port/forward corner of the Metropolis Atrium. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Shore Excursions Desk is in the port/forward corner of the Metropolis Atrium. The Shore Excursions Desk is in the port/forward corner of the Metropolis Atrium. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Metropolis Atrium is a soaring space that spans ten decks upward from the Metropolis Bar at its base. Peter Knego Fullscreen Directly aft of the Metroplis Atrium on the starboard side of Deck 2, the Alchemy Bar, which serves up cocktails made with fresh herbs and other exotic ingredients, is another Carnival signature venue that was added in April of 2015. Peter Knego Fullscreen Frankenstein’s Lab is a double-deck night club on aft Deck 2 that features an oversized “creature” and other Frankenstein motifs, including lightning bolt style lighting effects. Peter Knego Fullscreen Offering two fixed dinner seatings, the lower level of the grape-infused Bacchus Dining Room is located on aft Deck 2. This over-the-top space was conceived by former Carnival architect Joseph Farcus. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Ariadne Room is an annex to the Bacchus Dining Room that seats 86-guests. Peter Knego Fullscreen Used for a number of functions, including the nightly Punchliners Comedy Club, the 348 seat Alice In Wonderland-inspired Mad Hatter’s Ball is located on forward Riviera Deck (1). Peter Knego Fullscreen The Carnival Miracle has five self-service launderettes. Peter Knego Fullscreen Carnival Miracle has twelve accommodation categories. At the top end of the spectrum are six 430-square-foot Penthouse Suites with separate bedrooms and sitting areas. Peter Knego Fullscreen Penthouse Suites have original artworks, a living room nook, bar area and even a dressing area with a walk-in closet. Peter Knego Fullscreen Penthouse Suite bathrooms have granite tilework, double sinks, a toilet and a bidet. Peter Knego Fullscreen Penthouse Suite bathrooms also feature deluxe Jacuzzi tubs. Peter Knego Fullscreen Penthouse Suite balconies are lined in teakwood and are large enough to accommodate two loungers, a small table and two chairs. Peter Knego Fullscreen Located at the stern of the ship, 340-square-foot Vista Suites can be combined with the neighboring balcony stateroom. Peter Knego Fullscreen This is the living room of a Vista Suite. Like the Penthouse Suites, they also feature a private dressing area and walk-in closet. Peter Knego Fullscreen This is the bedroom of a Vista Suite. Peter Knego Fullscreen Vista Suites have wrap-around balconies that overlook the ship’s wake. Peter Knego Fullscreen Ocean Suites are smaller than Penthouse and Vista Suites but have similar amenities, including granite tiled bathrooms with Jacuzzi tubs and walk-in closets. Peter Knego Fullscreen Ocean Suites also have large, teak-lined balconies. Peter Knego Fullscreen Premium Balcony staterooms are smaller than suites but larger than standard balcony cabins. Peter Knego Fullscreen Premium Balcony staterooms feature granite-tiled bathrooms with a shower. Peter Knego Fullscreen Premium Balcony staterooms have wide, teak-lined balconies. Peter Knego Fullscreen Standard Balcony staterooms measure 220-square-feet and have twin or king sized bed configurations. Peter Knego Fullscreen Bathrooms in Balcony, Oceanview and Interior cabins are well designed modular units with sink, toilet, shower and plenty of storage space. Peter Knego Fullscreen This is a balcony on an aft-facing standard Balcony stateroom. Peter Knego Fullscreen Handicap-accessible Balcony staterooms are larger than average and feature wider doors and modified fixtures. Peter Knego Fullscreen Handicap-accessible stateroom bathrooms have roll-in showers with unfolding seats. Peter Knego Fullscreen Handicap-accessible Balcony stateroom balconies have wide doors and ramps on the balcony door sills. Peter Knego Fullscreen Oceanview staterooms are similar to Balcony staterooms but have large picture windows instead of balconies. Peter Knego Fullscreen Interior staterooms generally measure 185-square-feet and come in several configurations, including this comfortable twin. Peter Knego Fullscreen This Interior stateroom accommodates three with an unfolding upper berth. Peter Knego Fullscreen Like this topic?
